title: Wilfred Bennett Davidson-Houston
text:
Wilfred Bennett Davidson-Houston (3 January 1870 – 18 September 1960) was a British <a href="British%20Army">army</a> officer who fought in the <a href="Anglo-Ashanti%20wars">Anglo-Ashanti wars</a> and later became a colonial administrator in the <a href="British%20West%20Indies">British West Indies</a>.
Background.
Wilfred Bennett Davidson-Houston was born on 3 January 1870, the second son of Reverend B.C. Davidson-Houston of County Cork and Dublin.
He attended <a href="Corrig%20School">Corrig School</a>, <a href="Monkstown%2C%20County%20Dublin">Monkstown, County Dublin</a> in Ireland and <a href="St%20Edward%27s%20School%2C%20Oxford">St Edward's School, Oxford</a>.
Military career.
In 1887 Davidson-Houston was commissioned a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> with the 5th (<a href="Militia%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Militia</a>) battalion of the <a href="Royal%20Dublin%20Fusiliers">Royal Dublin Fusiliers</a>. He was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in 1889, <a href="Captain%20%28BARM%29">captain</a> on 26 November 1892, <a href="Major%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">major</a> on 11 October 1902 and <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant colonel</a> in 1906.
Davidson-Houston was assigned to the <a href="British%20South%20Africa%20Company">British South Africa Company</a> Police, and was assistant commissioner in <a href="Mashonaland">Mashonaland</a> (1890–1892).
He was assistant inspector of Gold Coast Hausas (1894) and captain of the West African Frontier Service, <a href="Kwahu">Kwahu</a> (1894–1895).
He served in the <a href="Fourth%20Anglo-Ashanti%20War">Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War</a> (1895–1896), and in subsequent operations in the Gold Coast (1897–1898), and was acting resident Ashanti (1899–1900).
He served in the Ashanti Campaign (1900) and the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Second Boer War</a> (1901–1902).
Colonial administrator.
In August 1902, he was seconded for service under the <a href="Colonial%20Office">Colonial Office</a>, and appointed commissioner of Ashanti (1902) and acting chief commissioner of Ashanti (1903–1905).
In 1906, Davidson-Houston was appointed commissioner of <a href="Montserrat">Montserrat</a> in the <a href="British%20West%20Indies">British West Indies</a>. 
During the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> he was D.A.Q.M.G. Central Force (1915), Eastern Command (1916), Headquarters 1st Army, B.E.F. (1917) and Deputy Controller of Labour, France (1918). 
He was administrator of <a href="Saint%20Lucia">Saint Lucia</a>, British West Indies (1918–1927). 
During this period he was several times acting governor of the <a href="Windward%20Islands">Windward Islands</a>.
Davidson-Houston was chief secretary, Nyasaland (1927–1930), and was twice acting governor, Nyasaland.
Davidson-Houston married Annie Henrietta, oldest daughter of land agent Colonel Edmond Langley Hunt, <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">C.M.G.</a>, of Curragh Bridge House, County Limerick (of a landed gentry family of Friarstown and Ballysinode), and they had two sons.
He retired in 1930. 
He died on 18 September 1960, aged ninety.
